data.title: Selfhost: imports from quick fix are relative and not absolute
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. use a type that is not imported in our source code
2. use quick fix to import it

=> the resulting import is relative with lots of ".."
=> ideally this import is in the typical form we use (vs/...)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/23247401/39c8f702-f99a-11e6-9dea-7b14bc140adc.png)

I think we need to set some root in our tsconfig.json for this to work?

data.title: SCM layout problem
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/23245386/e31d5410-f940-11e6-933e-3e0be03aa2ec.png)
 
- Type something in the commit input box, press shift+enter to insert a newline
- Don't type anything on the next line
- Click the file to open the diff view
- When I click the file, the viewlet shifts up a bit and obscures part of the commit message box

data.title: [extensions] Quickpick enhancements
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: `1.10.0-insider` 256d76fed7947e7289f921df10658d7a69233b65
- OS Version: macOS Sierra `10.12.3 (16D32)`

It would be great to have more control over a Quickpick. Here are some things I would love to have.

1. Stream or push items into a Quickpick (basically be able to show/add more items to the list as promises are resolved)
1. Update the placeholder dynamically
1. Control which item should be selected when shown
1. Add event for `right-arrow` press on an item, similar to the file access quickpick
1. Seed the inputbox with a value

data.title: Opening a file in my Downloads folder opens /
data.body: I'm guessing that vscode is checking whether the file is open a folder that has been opened before, and so defaults to `/` since I've opened it before? I never want to open `/` automatically though. It makes the file watcher go crazy and feels very odd.

data.title: Minimap lacks separation from editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (256d76fed7947e7289f921df10658d7a69233b65, 2017-02-22T07:04:54.544Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|autofilename|JerryHong|0.1.3|
|vscode-simple-icons|LaurentTreguier|0.10.0|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.11|
|azure-cli|chrmarti|0.3.0|
|regex|chrmarti|0.0.7|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.5|
|ghlink|dt|0.0.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|vscode-scss|mrmlnc|0.6.1|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.9.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.2|
|diff|rafaelmaiolla|0.0.1|
|vscode-open-in-github|sysoev|1.3.1|

---

Because their backgrounds are the same, it sometimes looks like a line is much shorter than it actually is below the minimap's colored content. E.g., line 123:
![screen shot 2017-02-22 at 3 04 03 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9205389/23237008/5033d1f4-f910-11e6-8291-5bf80f0bc038.png)

A simple fix might be to end the minimap where its content ends.

data.title: Using CTRL+p/n to navigate search results behaves differently than arrow keys
data.body:
#20440

**Repo**
On OSX

1. Open two editor groups.
1. Perform a search
1. Select the editor in the first group
1. Use arrow keys to navigate search result list. See that the active editor in the first group is changed when switching between files.
1. Use ctrl + p and ctrl + n to navigate the result list

**Bug**
Notice the editor in the second group is changed instead. 

If you make the second group active and use ctrl+p and ctrl + n to navigate, then a third editor group is opened.

data.title: Validate terminal links after they have been created
data.body: xterm.js could fire some validate callback which asks the consumer whether the link is valid and could then deactivate it if so.

data.title: Terminal links: url parameters value ignored
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10 insider
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open the terminal from VSCode and have it print an url with an url parameter, like `https://github.com/foo?param=ignored`

Click on the link: the page `https://github.com/foo?param` will be opened instead of the full url with parameters `https://github.com/foo?param=ignored`.

![terminallink](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/23236211/9e5e6fe0-f958-11e6-823f-6652d9a9d1ff.png)

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Keymap links are missing telemetry
Consider removing `${separator}` variable

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #20433

Currently, the default setting is rather difficult to read/parse. Is there any reason to include the separator string as a variable? (is it likely to change and is that something we want to optimize for?) If not, I think it would be much cleaner and readable to represent it as part of the string literal.
![screenshot from 2017-02-22 17-29-29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/23235703/83175a46-f924-11e6-8470-b90729dc0546.png)

data.title: Theme settings upgrade path - workspace theme setting isn't applied
data.body:
Testing #20998

If there is a workspace theme setting present when upgrading, it isn't applied.

- Have vscode 1.9
- In the workspace's settings.json, set `"workbench.colorTheme": "Red"` (maybe it was checked in to the project already)
- Set the color theme to something else like "Light+"
- Upgrade vscode
- Now the current theme is "Light+", and that's set in user settings. But the next time the settings.json is edited, or window is reloaded, the theme becomes "Red"
